Voyage on the Beagle

From December 27, 1831 to October 2, 1836, Charles Robert Darwin served as naturalist and unpaid assistant on the ship Beagle. During the five-year voyage around the world, Darwin observed and studied nature through a tremendous variety of plants and animals. These observations and studies led him to his theory of natural selection. This voyage changed not only Darwin's life and thought but also the general thinking about natural history and even the course of science.
